isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - IC BUS SERVICE MANUAL - SEATS - MAINTENANCE

svcprocinfo.para: The list below provides a general guideline for seat maintenance. These items should become part of a regular inspection program.

step1.para: Inspect and tighten all seat and barrier mounting hardware attachments. This should be performed at 30 to 45 day intervals. The seat leg bolts require 19 to 20 ft-lbs. of torque.
Inspect the mounting hardware at the seat cushion mount and seat clip.
Inspect the seat back foam around the upper corner and in the knee impact area. If damage is discovered such as breakage or separated seals, the seat back material should be replaced without delay.
Inspect the staples that attach the seat tacking strip.
Inspect the upholstery for cuts, markings and other damage.
When replacing seat back foam and upholstery, use OEM parts to ensure they meet manufacturer's requirements and federal standards.

svcsubproc.title: Upholstery Care and Cleaning Recommendations
svcsubproc.para: The upholstery vendor has supplied a list of solvents that are safe to use when cleaning the upholstery. These solvents, if properly used, will not harm the finish of the material. They are:

step1.para: Wash with mild soap and hot water to remove ordinary dirt, grime, etc.
Stubborn stains should be cleaned with alcohol. Odorless Mineral Spirits or VM&P Naphtha can be used to remove paint, tar, gum, shoe polish, etc. if alcohol does not remove the stain.
Isopropyl Alcohol and Denatured Alcohol are specifically recommended for cleaning stubborn dirt and stains.
Never clean upholstery with polish remover, Graffiti Eater® strong caustic or acidic agents or any cleaners with active solvents like MEK, Tolual, gasoline, etc.
